body: UPDATE : after reading the presentation from Damian, the "slides" option looks much more complex than I thought, so the issues I see may not be pertinent, so I prefer to close this issue.

let's leave this open and try to figure this out for 2.0 "slide" is not that much more complicated than others converters and if you hit a bug there are chances it is present elsewhere. It is just a little hard right now to debug as we are close to release, and few peoples have windows installed (which is a vicious circle for bugs)

Ok, 

I'm personally testing on Windows by 
- creating (another) temporary  winpython directory,
- then updating it by pip install http://archive.ipython.org/testing/.../ipython-....tar.gz 

It would be nice if you could provide a few intermediate 2.0 snapshots in archive.ipython.org/testing 
(a snapshot of  the week each friday  ?)

> a snapshot of the week each friday ?

No need for snapshot, master should be alway usable . On python 2.7 a git pull is enough to upgrade,
hopefully it will be the same for python3 soon right now you just have rerun `setup.py install`.

I'm lost in thought trying to figure what is wrong.
A comparative example may help.

Do you have a typical example of 
- a basic .ipynb with an image (like a matplotlib example) 
- and it's correctly generated "--to slides" result

So I can compare with what I get and see the maybe very small detail that is missing. (so I have a small chance to have it resolved before 1.0.0)

ok, if I understand well the issue 
- in the initial .ipynb , the image is stored as :  "png": "iVBORw...blabla..RU5ErkJggg==\n",
- in the "--to HTML" conversion it is unfortunately still referenced as  img src="data:image/png;base64,b'iVBORw..blabla..Jggg==\n'
  (instead of being first transformed back in a  .png file and having the html pointing to it)
- in the "--to latex" conversion,  the same "png": "iVBORw...blabla..RU5ErkJggg==\n" is rightly converted in a  temporary png file ("first_try_files/first_try_3_0.png").

the difference is the extract output transformer, which currently only runs for the latex exporter by default.  You can enable it for slides as well, but you would have to change the reveal template to use the output filenames instead of the embedded images.
@stonebig Thanks for reporting this.  I have a copy of Windows on my machine too.  I'll go ahead and boot into Windows to see if I can track this down.

> in the "--to HTML" conversion it is unfortunately still referenced as img src="data:image/png;base64,b'iVBORw..blabla..Jggg==\n' (instead of being first transformed back in a .png file and having the html pointing to it)

why unfortunate ? this is perfectly valid and should work in reveal. It does work on nbviewer

ah , even if I just do a "--to HTML" ?
(I was trying to narrow down the "--to slides" problem by trying the simpler option)

I do click on the generated html, like if nothing exist but a standard browser and the .html file.

Isn't it the way it's meant to be played ?

Late, but sure...
OK, regarding Mathjax, the current implementation is not able to detect the local installed mathjax a use it...
Nor for slides neither from HTML formats... you can change this behavior just modifying the templates to load the js file from a local dir... Making this selection automatic would be interesting, but I do no think we can make it for 1.0 release...

> the difference is the extract output transformer, which currently only runs for the latex exporter by default. You can enable it for slides as well, but you would have to change the reveal template to use the output filenames instead of the embedded images.

If this is the problem (probably) you have to change the basic_html template because full_html and reveal templates are inherited from this basic_html template which is dealing with the basic blocks at lower level...

ah ok,

I did the remark because   
- one intended use could be in situations where internet is disabled,
- in my example, I think (not 100% sure, though) mathjax was just not used.

> one intended use could be in situations were internet is disabled,

Yes, this is a use case, I will add it to my to-do list for enhancements ;-)

Serve error tested and verified on my machine too.  I don't have the same problem you do with embedded images though...

Pull Request #3943 fixes it

Hello jdfreder

This morning I retry the same things with python 2.7 (instead of 3.3 only until now)

Python 2.7 

---

   "--to html " was ok even in rc1.

Python 3.3 (after setup.py install from this morning master)

---

It's still not ok on my Python3.3 for "--to html" : no image when doing 

  ipython3 nbconvert "C:/blabla/first_try.ipynb" --to html

I hope it's only my installation that has gone south

ok I found what's wrong on my python3 , the image base 64 is plagged by "\n" suite of characters
in python2 those characters are properly converted to "Go to Next Line"

my bad python3 =
mg src="data:image/png;base64,b'iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAV0AAADtCAYAAAAcNaZ2AAAABHNCSVQICAgIfAhkiAAAAAlwSFlz\nAAALEg...blabla..

my good python2 =
mg src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAV0AAADtCAYAAAAcNaZ2AAAABHNCSVQICAgIfAhkiAAAAAlwSFlz
AAALEg...blabla..

>  on my python3 , the image base 64 is plagged by "\n" suite of characters

This is very helpful, thanks @stonebig !

Trying to digg a little further
nbconvert starts by loading the notebook 
  in nbconvert\exporters\exporter.py
  by using the standard function nbformat\nbformat.read(f, 'json') 

This standard functions returns under  python2.7
...blabla..., u'outputs': [{u'output_type': u'display_data', u'metadata': {}, u'png': u'iVBOR...Flz\nAAALEg...blabla

and returns under  python3.3  
...blabla..., 'outputs': [{'output_type': 'display_data', 'metadata': {}, 'png': b'iVBOR...Flz\nAAALEg...blabla...

So the bad "b'" seems to be there from the start of the treatment.
 ... don't you have the same issue under Linux with a Python 3.3 ?

@stonebig I don't think the string stored as a byte array is the problem as long as it is parsed correctly.  See the following code from my Win7 Python 3 notebook-

In[8]:

``` python
    a = b'hello\nworld'
    a
```

```
b'hello\nworld'
```

In[9]:

``` python
    from IPython.utils import py3compat as py3
    print(a)
    print(py3.bytes_to_str(a))
```

```
b'hello\nworld'
hello
world
```

ok. but "py3.bytes_to_str()" is independant from the fact we are or not under windows. 

So a linux  box with python 3.3 should have a small chance of sharing the same problem. 
(I feel a little as an orphan disease with my windows + python3.3)

*nix + Python 3.3 may share the same problem, but what I was trying to say is that the binary strings in the notebook JSON (that 'b' you see) is not the root cause of the problem.  We intentionally store the data that way.  The problem is in the way nbconvert is parsing the image data.  I just wanted to show to you that it's okay to store the data in that form and still parse it correctly.

I'm testing on Windows + Python 3.3 too.
So, If I understood any bit of nbconvert,  the problem is that we forgot to tell to jinja that "py3.bytes_to_str()" is to be called when processing  a "data_png" block  ?
Yes, better put, we need to call _bytes_to_str_ correctly for Jinja (before we pass it in).  The weird thing is, I think we are calling it, so I'm not quite sure where the hose clog is.
(I'm away from my desktop right now so I can't actually debug this issue, but later tonight I'll take a closer look)

I'm not sure they are cast'ed or `bytes_to_string`'ed when the output extract transformer is not on. they are most probably be passed as is. We might probably need either a on by default transformer, or a filter apply directly in jinja.

We might want to backport such a fix to 1.1, but need to be much more carefull as we will allow arbitrary mime type for v4 format and we can't hardcode wether each mime type is binary or not. I still think we should store them separately, or with a flag to differentiate.
or we should deal with that at nbformat-reader level.

Travis says  (if I did it right, and my test is right)
the problem is present for python 3.2 and  python 3.3 

in current master, 
    https://travis-ci.org/stonebig/ipython/builds/10191309

in branch 1.x 
     https://travis-ci.org/stonebig/ipython/builds/10148889

```
@dec.onlyif_cmds_exist('pandoc')
def test_png_base64_html_ok(self):
    """
    is png base64 well formed in HTML ?
    """
    with self.create_temp_cwd(['notebook2.ipynb']):
        self.call('nbconvert --log-level 0 --to HTML '
                  'notebook2.ipynb --template full ')
        assert os.path.isfile('notebook2.html')
        with open('notebook2.html') as f:
            assert "data:image/png;base64,b'" not in f.read()
```

#4043 seems to fix the issue. 
Hourra for minRK   \o/ ... \o/ ... \o/ ... !
